items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels have risen at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight 15/03/2023. We expect river levels to remain high beyond 16/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff have closed the pointing doors at Torksey. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:30 tonight, 15/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible in this area. 
 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.  
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Lake levels on Derwentwater are currently rising again following some heavy rainfall overnight over high ground. There has been further rain throughout this morning (Thursday 16/03/23), which should turn lighter and more intermittent by this afternoon. Friday (17/03/23) is now looking somewhat brighter with scattered showers.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site which has been already subject to flooding.
We will continue to monitor water levels closely as they have risen above the Flood Warning level again this morning (16/03/23) and not expected to peak till late evening. Continue to take care and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00pm on Friday (17/03/2023), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Heavy rainfall over high ground overnight has seen some response from upland rivers and streams early this morning (Thursday 16/03/23) but they will begin to peak as this current rain band clears through. Further flooding to low lying land and roads is still possible. Further rain is expected throughout this morning (16/03/23), which should turn lighter and more intermittent by this afternoon. Friday (17/03/23) is looking somewhat brighter with scattered showers. The level of Derwentwater will continue to rise throughout the day and will not peak till late this evening. A Flood Warning remains in Force for Keswick Campsite and areas adjacent the lake shores and we will continue to closely monitor the situation. Continue to take care and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on Friday at 12:00pm (17/03/2023) or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise overnight Wednesday (15/03/23) due to prolonged rain, falling on already saturated ground.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible from the early hours of Thursday morning (16/03/23), continuing throughout the day.
It is possible that some flood warning thresholds could be reached.
Rainfall amounts are expected to be less on Friday (17/03/23) which should allow river levels to recede.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor river levels and this alert will be updated on Friday or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are currently falling, but are expected to begin rising again this evening, Thursday 16/03/23, with levels in York expected to peak on Friday afternoon. Peak levels are forecast to be similar to those seen earlier this week, before falling back down into the weekend. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday, 17/03/2023.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise overnight Wednesday (15/03/23) due to prolonged rain, falling on already saturated ground.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible from the early hours of Thursday morning (16/03/23), continuing throughout the day.
We do not currently expect flood warning thresholds to be reached.
Rainfall amounts are expected to be less on Friday (17/03/23) which should allow river levels to recede.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor river levels and this alert will be updated on Friday or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse are currently falling, but are expected to begin rising again this evening, Thursday 16/03/23, with levels in York expected to peak on Friday afternoon. Peak levels are forecast to be similar to those seen earlier this week, before falling back down into the weekend. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday, 17/03/2023.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault and Welney river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Thursday 16 March, and is likely to continue for the next few days. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes including the causeways at Sutton Gault and Welney. This information is correct as of 07:45 on Thursday 16 March. The Welney causeway currently has 35cm of water on the road and the causeway at Sutton Gault has 33cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Further rainfall is forecast over the rest of the week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 16/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible from the early hours of Thursday morning (16/03/23), continuing throughout the day.
It is possible that some flood warning thresholds could be reached.
Rainfall amounts are expected to be less on Friday (17/03/23) which should allow river levels to recede.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor river levels and this alert will be updated on Friday or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Recent rainfall overnight has caused the River Dee to rise. It should peak at about noon today15 March 2023 at 8.7 metres but will continue to be high until Friday morning 17th March fluctuating between 8.5 and 8.7 metres due to further rainfall tonight and tomorrow. Access to Townfield Lane is currently cut off. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated Friday morning, 17/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for unsettled weather up to, and including, the weekend.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as river levels remain high on the River Derwent due to recent rain and snowmelt. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent and Scarborough areas, including land around the Sea Cut at Low Marishes, Throxenby Beck, Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton. Levels are expected to remain high overnight and throughout Friday, 17/03/2023. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Friday, 17/03/2023.

We have seen heavy rainfall and snow melt in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high over the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or out buildings is possible close to the river. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated as the situation changes.
